Problem:
Consider the complex function \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \), where \( \omega \) is a real constant. This function describes a rotation in the complex plane. We examine the interactions between the Fourier transform \( \mathcal{F} \) and a linear operator \( L \) defined by \( Lf(t) = tf(t) \) on function \( z(t) \).

If the linear operator \( L \) is applied to \( z(t) \) at \( t = 0 \), and then \( z(t) \) is allowed to evolve over time without further function manipulation, will the Fourier transform \( \mathcal{F}[Lz(t)] \) at \( t = T \) be the same as the Fourier transform directly applied to the evolved \( z(t) \) under the same conditions?
Explanation: The application of \( L \) to \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \) results in \( Lz(t) = t e^{i\omega t} \). The Fourier transform of \( Lz(t) \) involves differentiating the original transform, which includes a frequency shift and scaling, differing significantly from the Fourier transform of \( z(t) \) without applying \( L \).
